Award.AwardTitle: Hydrophilic Macroionic Solutions - the Roles of Counterions, Co-ions and Surface Water Layers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Tianbo Liu of the University of Akron explores the solution properties of macroions. These macroions are between 1 and 10 nanometers (nm) in size and represent a missing link between simple ions and large colloids. The project aims to explore the microscopic features of macroions and their interactions with local environments, that is, the counterions, the co-ions, and the layered structures they make in water. These interactions are being explored in order to unveil the fundamental reasons behind the unique solution properties of the macroions such as their self-assembly into blackberry-like structures. The blackberry formation process is found to mimic the virus capsid formation process. This research could have broad impacts on other fields, such as physical chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, biochemistry, materials sciences and nanotechnology. The project involves training graduate and undergraduate students, and encouraging high school students to participate in national science competitions and scientific careers. The research infrastructure is being enhanced through scientific collaborations.

The research has three complementary components. First, the macroion-counterion interaction is being characterized by determining the radial distributions of counterions around macroions and the stability of the macroions in the presence of an excess number of counterions. Secondly, the effect of co-ions on the macroions are being examined, particularly for the preferential interactions between chiral macroions and chiral co-ions. Third, the detailed changes of surface water structures of both counterions and macroions during their interaction are being studied. Relatively simple models, mainly polyoxometalate clusters and metal-organic nanocages, are employed for the study. The solution studies employ a combination of techniques, such as static and dynamic laser light scattering, synchrotron small-angle X-ray scattering, isothermal titration, nuclear magnetic resonance, electron microscopy, and Zeta potential analysis. The conclusions are expected to be universal and may be instructive for understanding more complex systems such as polyelectrolyte and biomacromolecular solutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
?Macroionic solutions ? the roles of counterions, co-ions and surface water layers?. (Sep. 2016 ? August 2020)

Intellectual merit: This grant supported the PI (Tianbo Liu, Department of Polymer Science, The University of Akron) to explore the unique solution behaviors of various hydrophilic macroions, whose sizes (1-5 nm) are in between of simple ions and colloidal particles and whose solution behaviors cannot be described by the above two categories. Macroions are nanoscale soluble ions represented by a broad range of examples from inorganic clusters, metal-organic cages, dendrimers to biomacromolecules. They share many common features, all related to the interactions among their major components: macroions, counterions, co-ions and hydration layers. The self-assembly of macroions into hollow, spherical, single-layered ?blackberry?-type structures due to counterion-mediated attraction is universal for various macroions, highlighting the obvious like-charge attraction feature due to the effect of counterion association around macroions. The electrostatic interaction-driven assembly shows interesting features such as the self-recognition feature among similar macroions during their self-assembly, and the capability of interacting and distinguishing counterions accurately in dilute solution. The PI?s group has focused on understanding the detailed roles of counterions, co-ions and the hydration layers of macroions on the solution behaviors of macroions, such as the counterion distribution and replacement around macroions, the stabilization effect of co-ions, and the breakage of hydration layers during the macroion-counterion interaction and self-assembly. Particularly, the PI?s group explored the roles of counterions and co-ions around chiral macroions, especially on the chiral-recognition and chiral selection between chiral enantiomeric macroions. The observed chiral recognition and separation features might be directly related to the homochirality phenomenon during the origin of life. Meanwhile, simulations efforts have been developed to successfully explain and predict experimental data.

Broad impact: The macroionic solutions are different from simple ions and colloids, offering mew opportunities to physical, colloidal and biophysical sciences. The current grant helps to link areas in different fields, from physical chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, biochemistry to materials sciences, and educate students at different levels. The electrostatic interaction in the model systems explored in the past years helps understand more complicated solution systems. Since 2016, eight Ph.D. students and twelve M.S. students have received their degrees; and the PI has delivered >30 invited talks in national/international conferences and other institutions during this period of time. Totally 28 papers have been published with the support of this grant.
